Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The nun has a quiet afternoon and plans to spend time in personal spiritual reading and contemplation.
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread before me, the hum of the convent’s old radiator a gentle background to my thoughts. As an engineer, I was expected to sketch out preliminary ideas for the new water filtration system, even though the project was still in its early stages. My mind buzzed with possibilities—should I propose a solar-powered design, or wait until more data came in? There was time, I reminded myself; nothing was urgent yet.

But the clock ticked toward the hour I’d set aside for spiritual reading. As a nun, I was expected to nurture my soul, to spend quiet afternoons in reflection and prayer. The Psalms waited on my bedside table, their pages promising peace and clarity. Yet, the technical questions tugged at me, refusing to be silenced. I felt torn, the weight of both callings pressing in—one demanding innovation and foresight, the other inviting stillness and surrender. My heart ached with the tension, unsure which voice to heed as the afternoon sun slanted through the window.
